Answer: Blockchain is a distributed, unchangeable ledger that makes recording transactions and managing assets in a corporate network much easier. A tangible asset (a house, car, cash, or land) can be intangible (intellectual property, patents, copyrights, branding). On a blockchain network, virtually anything of value may be recorded and traded, lowering risk and cutting costs for all parties involved.Each transaction is verified to ensure its validity. This verification process is completed by the computers connected to the network, each of which independently checks to ensure that the trade is legiBlockchain is a distributed, unchangeable ledger that makes recording transactions and managing assets in a corporate network much easier. A tangible asset (a house, car, cash, or land) can be intangible (intellectual property, patents, copyrights, branding). On a blockchain network, virtually anything of value may be recorded and traded, lowering risk and cutting costs for all parties involved.Each transaction is verified to ensure its validity. This verification process is completed by the computers connected to the network, each of which independently checks to ensure that the trade is legitimate.Once verified, each transaction is added to a block that gets hashed. “Blocks” are basically groups of transaction records, and each one is unique. Each block also carries a code known as a hash value (or hash digest),The hash also ensures the integrity of the data to show that it hasn’t been modified since it was recorded in the block.Once complete, the block is added to the end of the blockchain. This brings us to the end of the blockchain creation and verification process. Once one block is complete, another block will start

Answer: Blockchain is a system of recording information in a way that makes it difficult or impossible to change, hack, or cheat the system. A blockchain is essentially a digital ledger of transactions that is duplicated and distributed across the entire network of computer systems on the blockchain.There have been many attempts to create digital money in the past, but they have always failed.The prevailing issue is trust. If someone creates a new currency called the X dollar, how can we trust that they won't give themselves a million X dollars, or steal your X dollars for themselves?Bitcoin was desigBlockchain is a system of recording information in a way that makes it difficult or impossible to change, hack, or cheat the system. A blockchain is essentially a digital ledger of transactions that is duplicated and distributed across the entire network of computer systems on the blockchain.There have been many attempts to create digital money in the past, but they have always failed.The prevailing issue is trust. If someone creates a new currency called the X dollar, how can we trust that they won't give themselves a million X dollars, or steal your X dollars for themselves?Bitcoin was designed to solve this problem by using a specific type of database called a blockchain. Most normal databases, such as an SQL database, have someone in charge who can change the entries (e.g. giving themselves a million X dollars). Blockchain is different because nobody is in charge; it’s run by the people who use it. What’s more, bitcoins can’t be faked, hacked or double spent – so people that own this money can trust that it has some value.

Answer: Bitcoin source code is open- that’s easy target.But before that learn to pack data into a c like structure and dump it in hex format. Then learn how to calculate sha256 of the structure. Lean about linked lists.Next learn about markle tree data structure (Learn how to do math operations on large numbers (like 256 bit numbers).If you want a scriptable block chain you need to learn about how to program lower level languages like assembly language. You can design your own instruction set. A stack based simple exBitcoin source code is open- that’s easy target.But before that learn to pack data into a c like structure and dump it in hex format. Then learn how to calculate sha256 of the structure. Lean about linked lists.Next learn about markle tree data structure (Learn how to do math operations on large numbers (like 256 bit numbers).If you want a scriptable block chain you need to learn about how to program lower level languages like assembly language. You can design your own instruction set. A stack based simple execution engine should work.At this point you should start defining the block header structure and how each transaction, a list of transactions and how the markle root should be stored in the header as well as previous block header hash.Now you may start to look at block chain implementations (on github) in many different languages. AlsoThe technology is not very difficult - but you need to do a lot of testing before you can consider it to be stable for wide use.Good luck!

question: https://www.quora.com/I-want-to-learn-more-and-be-a-blockchain-programmer-where-should-I-start

Answer: You can’t, because blockchain is not a “thing”. That’s like saying you want to study the internet, or study the cloud. Blockchain is a category of technologies that covers distributed computing, cryptography, and others. Looking at the other answers, it is also obvious that a lot of non-tech people are mixing blockchain and cryptocurrencies together, thinking they’re one and the same things.Here’s what you need to learn, if you want to do “blockchain” stuff. Start with learning about distributed systems, and get your programming game on. Go through the classic papers like Two Generals Problem,You can’t, because blockchain is not a “thing”. That’s like saying you want to study the internet, or study the cloud. Blockchain is a category of technologies that covers distributed computing, cryptography, and others. Looking at the other answers, it is also obvious that a lot of non-tech people are mixing blockchain and cryptocurrencies together, thinking they’re one and the same things.Here’s what you need to learn, if you want to do “blockchain” stuff. Start with learning about distributed systems, and get your programming game on. Go through the classic papers like Two Generals Problem, Byzantine Generals Problem, FLP Impossibility Proof, Paxos, and then ask yourself, do you know how to coordinate a network of individual nodes that needs to reach consensus of some sort. Then read the bitcoin whitepaper and learn why is it different from the normal paxos algorithm. That should equip you with enough foundational knowledge to evaluate blockchain technologies, and find ways to implement them in real world scenarios.Make sure you are comfortable with programming, internet protocols, basic cryptographic algorithms, consensus algorithms, and basic distributed computing principles. These can be acquired by getting a computer science degree, and working in tech companies with sufficient data for you to play around with.Good luck!

Answer: One of the advantages of having a few years on the clock… you’ve seen it all before:What does the whole list have in common (aside from costing heaps and rarely delivering??)Like so much in IT,I don’One of the advantages of having a few years on the clock… you’ve seen it all before:What does the whole list have in common (aside from costing heaps and rarely delivering??)Like so much in IT,I don’t think blockchain is anywhere near production ready.Its expensive, slow, doesn’t scale and is highly vulnerable to attack from parties with significant means (Governments or large corporates AKA 51% attack EG if I have more nodes/hashing power than you, I become the source of truth etc).As other have said, get a good general understanding of software development lifecycles, how modern IT infrastructure works IE cloud computing, serverless, docker etc.Learn methodologies Scrum/Agile, lean, kanban, waterfall etc.If you did want to play around with blockchain as a side hustle, this is a cut/paste from a previous reply of technologies I would familiarise yourself with:Technology wise, I would start with the basics:One of the best things you can do for yourself, create a test blockchain on your home computer:

question: https://www.quora.com/Why-is-Go-a-good-language-for-developing-blockchain-technology

Answer: Blockchain and Data Science are emerging as among the most popular technology trends. It is an undeniable fact that every company needs to have secure records of financial transaction data. Simultaneously, the need to expand the services and products of a company by targeted advertisement is fulfilled by the application of Data Science.Let us learn more about these vital technological applications and compare them:Blockchain vs Data ScienceThough Blockchain is considered to be a recent technological application, it could be described as the missing piece of the puzzle. The reason is that sinceBlockchain and Data Science are emerging as among the most popular technology trends. It is an undeniable fact that every company needs to have secure records of financial transaction data. Simultaneously, the need to expand the services and products of a company by targeted advertisement is fulfilled by the application of Data Science.Let us learn more about these vital technological applications and compare them:Blockchain vs Data ScienceThough Blockchain is considered to be a recent technological application, it could be described as the missing piece of the puzzle. The reason is that since Blockchain entered the digital world, its direct impact is seen in the transaction systems across all the domains. Blockchain is a concept used in many other fields as well. The reason that makes the area unique is that it works on the principle of Consensus Problem.Coming to Data Science, this field deals with analytics. It means the discovery, interpretation, and communication of meaningful patterns in data. Finding solutions to a problem by analysing a large amount of data to bring out efficient production and services to clients. Problem-solving abilities have always existed, but with the help of computational power, there has been a significant boost to evaluate solutions for Marketing, Finance, Human Resources, Health Care, Government Policies and every possible industry where data gets generatedScope Of BlockchainThe use of Blockchain does not restrict only to financial services. Since the idea of Blockchain is to maintain a series of time-stamped recorded data, it can be used in other services such as the medical sector. In the pharmaceutical industry, it can be used to make medical records of patients that are organised with accurate data and sorted according to patient history.Furthermore, in the property sector, land records that can be dealt with Blockchain as the ownership of a piece of land can change multiple times. To have a time-stamped series of data helps in data sorting and verifying the ownership in property-related matters. Moreover, Blockchain Developers can easily earn around INR 10 LPA and above.Other fields of Blockchain application include:Scope Of Data ScienceIn the simplest of terms, Data Science is a concept based on the union of three multidisciplinary fields, namely:Data Science uses various aspects of these three disciplines and evolves into a profession which requires one to work closely with data. Mining of data, analysing it, drawing patterns and interpreting them are expected from a Data Scientist. The theme “Data Science for prediction and Blockchain for Data Integrity” makes things clear. Undeniably, Data Science has a lot of applications but therein lies the limitations as well. Data Science can be used only as long as the input data is genuine. The sorting and processing of data while applying algorithms and statistical inputs is a massive computational task. But the exciting catch here is that Blockchain, too, to an extent, works on data with more straightforward computational efforts.Requirements Of Data ScienceAlthough every field under Computer Science has its application, there are some fields which require extra efforts and thorough knowledge of many languages and concepts. You need to know your way around Spark, Hadoop, Hive, Pig, SQL, Neo4J, MySQL, Python, R, Scala, Tensorflow, A/B Testing, NLP. Because of these high criteria, many Data Scientists are not delighted with their jobs as the expectations do not meet reality. It is estimated that many ML specialists and Data Scientists were looking for new job opportunities.Requirements Of BlockchainBlockchain has relatively less complicated concepts to deal with. Majorly, it involves concepts related to distributed databases and cryptography. Furthermore, Blockchain requires basic languages taught at the graduation level, such as Java, Golang, Rust, Scala, Haskell, Erlang, Python, C, C++, C#. The critical point to note is that anyone can gain these skills in 3 months and start working on professional development level in maybe 10–12 months.How To Learn?Although Blockchain plays such a vital role in many domains, it is not taught as a distinct subject in Universities and Colleges.There are many online educational sources such as upGrad where there are high-quality tutorials and blogs to make the concept easier to learn. Since these decisions impact your future, it is critical to choose a domain which you are passionate about and can reach a dynamic career growth.

Answer: At BoxCat, we spent a lot of time thinking about our initial technology stack and operational stack.I come from a corporate background, so a lot of our decisions were based on survival of the business, probability of revenue, and ease of development/overhead.Running your own small game studio takes a lot of planning. Free free to ask questions about our choices in the comments.Our games:Focused on iOS for now. 70% of mobile revenue comes through apple, while apple holds only 30% of the install base over all smartphones globally. That means android has a lot of users, but most of them are not wAt BoxCat, we spent a lot of time thinking about our initial technology stack and operational stack.I come from a corporate background, so a lot of our decisions were based on survival of the business, probability of revenue, and ease of development/overhead.Running your own small game studio takes a lot of planning. Free free to ask questions about our choices in the comments.Our games:Focused on iOS for now. 70% of mobile revenue comes through apple, while apple holds only 30% of the install base over all smartphones globally. That means android has a lot of users, but most of them are not willing to spend money.3D is expensive, so we went with a 2D engine. There are more artists we can collaborate with that do high quality 2D than there are for good 3D.Cocos2D gave us the best touch control API. We felt like we could do more with cocos2D than Unity.Objective-C is a bit easier to program in than C++, so we choose Objective-C. This locked us into the apple platform. However looking back, we should have used C++. It will take some time to port our in-house tools to C++ so we can expand to Android.TexturePacker, great tool by Code'n Web. Just drop your 2D sprites in and it will compact, compress, and compile them for you to use in Cocos2D.Particle Designer, great tool by 71Squared. Makes it super ease to build particle systems and to overlay them over each other to have a quick view of what they might look like in-game.In other to make our lives easier, we made an engine on top of cocos2D. It does quite a few things for us. Sorry, these are propriety. Hopefully it gives you a sense of how a game studio needs to invent their own tools to be productive.TouchOrganizer, a library that collects and algorithmically sorts multi-touch into individual touch point objects. This allows us to track multi-tap, single-double-multiple repeats, drag-drop-hold over 11 touch points (iOS hardware max).Cutscenes Scripting Engine, a library that allows us to script cutscenes animation sequences. Works by keyframes and simplifies the programming process so that non-programmers can participate on the content pipeline.Data manager, a globally accessible datastructure that allows us to quickly toggle and change values to control game flow.GUI manager, a push-pop dialog management library. Makes development much easier and faster. Allows us to prototype dialogs and gui in a few minutes.Distributed CDN engine, we can leverage multiple CDNs at the same time. Effectivilitly purchasing their lowest (usually free) pricing teir and create a stable and highly available CDN download for update files.C++ based backend server for data management and transfer. Used to be a server guy, so we built a highly scalable client management system we're trying out in our next game. Excited :)A lot of others: CSV file reader, encryption, state machines, TcpIp stuff, parsers, pathing A* libraries, etc...Operationally we use the following services because they are stable, powerful, and inexpensive.Google apps for email and domain.Dropbox for shared filesMediaFire for more shared filesGoogle Drive for more shared files!!We also use DropBox for prototyping, we load screenshots on the Dropbox app and tap on it as if it were implemented.Unfuddle for SVN source code control.Google analyticsTrello for to do tasks as a teamFor everyday tasks, everyone at the studio uses TaskCat. We made this out of frustration. Today's daily task lists are too bloated. This one makes it simple. (AppStore: http://tc.box.cat/)Hope this helps!
